properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain at times heavy today and tonight. A low pressure system will bring rain to regions along the west shore of Lake Superior this morning, then to regions along the north and east shore of Lake Superior this afternoon and this evening. General rainfall amounts are expected to be 20 to 30 mm. However, it is possible that some areas could receive up to 50 mm by Tuesday morning. Localized flooding is possible. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T01:09:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T09:10:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0831811456.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds tonight and early Monday morning. A low pressure centre will move right over Victoria late this evening and then quickly move through the Lower Mainland overnight. The southeast winds have increased to 50 km/h gusting to 70 over communities near southern Georgia Strait and Haro Strait. Behind the low overnight, winds will shift to west 50 km/h gusting to 70 to 90 near Juan de Fuca Strait. The westerlies will ease on Monday morning. Currently, the track and depth of the low suggest wind speeds will stay just below warning thresholds but some power outages are still likely. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T16:49:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T02:27:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2494167963.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong low pressure system is expected to impact the eastern Kitikmeot starting late Monday afternoon and will continue through to Thursday October 15, 2020. Expected conditions over the region include: Strong easterly winds gusting to 70 km/h, heavy snowfall and blowing snow. Additionally, there is a slight chance of freezing rain over the region. Total snowfall amounts associated with this system remain uncertain at this point in time, but could range between 10-30 cm by Thursday afternoon. As the system approaches and confidence regarding the conditions and impacts increases, the Winter Storm Watches may be upgraded to Winter Storm Warnings. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T19:27:13-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T03:28:13-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2152021063.2020
Area: Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong low pressure system is expected to impact the eastern Kitikmeot starting late this afternoon and will continue through to Thursday October 15, 2020. The exact track of the system is still uncertain. Expected conditions over the region include: Strong easterly winds gusting to 70 km/h, heavy snowfall, blowing snow, and a risk of freezing rain. Total snowfall amounts associated with this system remain uncertain at this point in time, but could range between 10-30 cm by Thursday afternoon. As the system approaches and confidence regarding the conditions and impacts increases, the Winter Storm Watches may be upgraded to Winter Storm Warnings. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Winter storm watches are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Frost Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Frost may damage frost-sensitive fruit trees and vegetable plants. Conditions will be favourable for frost tonight especially in low lying areas. ### Frost advisories are issued when temperatures are expected to reach the freezing mark during the growing season, leading to potential damage and destruction to plants and crops. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Rainfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. Rain will begin this morning and become heavy this afternoon. Total rainfall amounts near 50 mm are expected before rain tapers off this evening. Localized flooding is possible. For information concerning flooding, please consult your local Conservation Authority or Ontario Ministry of Natural Resources and Forestry District Office. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter conditions are expected. Heavy snow is expected to start late this evening and continue until Tuesday night, with total snow accumulations of up to 30 cm possible. Strong winds with gusts to 80 km/h tonight and into Tuesday morning will give blowing snow. ### Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Heavy snow over the Pennask and Kootenay Pass summits will taper off early this morning. Another round of snow is expected beginning tonight, with an additional 15 to 20 cm possible through Tuesday morning. A series of fast moving frontal systems combined with falling freezing levels is giving snow over the high elevation mountain passes. The first system brought heavy snow to Pennask Summit and Kootenay Pass overnight. Snow will ease off early this morning as this system departs. The next system will approach tonight. Snow levels will lower to near 1000 m. Snow, heavy at times, will begin overnight and will taper off in the afternoon Tuesday. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T01:35:38-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T09:36:38-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1307507111.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Paulson Summit to Kootenay Pass, Okanagan Connector - Merritt to Kelowna
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A deepening low will approach Vancouver Island tonight. Ahead of the low winds will rise to southeast 90 km/h gusting to 110 over the exposed coastal sections of North Vancouver Island overnight. Winds will ease late Tuesday morning as the low pushes onto Vancouver Island and weakens. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T03:53:13-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Another round of snow is expected tonight for BC highway passes. A frontal system moving across BC brought snow to the high elevation highway passes overnight. Snow will taper off early this morning over most routes. Another frontal systems will move through southern BC tonight. This systems will once again usher in colder air which will cause snow levels to fall to near 1000 m overnight. Snow is expected to begin overnight, before changing over to rain Tuesday as snow levels rise. For Allison Pass (Hope to Princeton): An additional 10 cm is expected overnight and Tuesday morning. For Coquihalla Summit (Hope to Merritt): An additional 5 to 10 cm is possible tonight. For Surrey Summit (Merritt to Kamloops): 5 cm is possible late tonight and early Tuesday morning. For Rogers Pass (Revelstoke to Golden): 5 cm is expected this morning, with an additional 10 cm Tuesday. ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-13T03:34:30-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-12T11:35:30-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0364231783.2020
Area: Highway 3 - Hope to Princeton via Allison Pass, Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt, Coquihalla Highway - Merritt to Kamloops, Trans-Canada Highway - Eagle Pass to Rogers Pass

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre off the west coast of Vancouver Island will move over Victoria late this evening and then move inland overnight. Strong southeast winds currently observed in Victoria will veer to the southwest this evening. As the low crosses near midnight, winds will quickly shift to west 40 to 60 km/h with gusts of 90 km/h near Juca de Fuca Strait. Winds will ease Monday morning as the low departs. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-10-12T15:02:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-10-11T23:03:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4022804817.2020
Area: Greater Victoria
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre will approach the South Coast tonight and then move across Vancouver Island on Tuesday morning. Winds will rise to southeast 70 gusting to 100 km/h over Western Vancouver Island late this evening before rising to southeast 60 gusting to 90 km/h overnight for areas near northern Georgia Strait. Winds will ease on Tuesday morning as the low centre pushes onto Vancouver Island and weakens. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
